div.p: Greetings. I commend to you, my most esteemed lord, my son-in-law, who has been held by a remarkable eagerness to visit you, and now indeed fulfills this desire of his. He has joined himself as a companion to a most excellent man, whom I also hope will be most pleasing to you.
I entrust to you, my old friend and most esteemed lord, a token of friendship, these my discourses on the Lord's Supper, and I wish you well in Christ with all yours.
Zurich, 9th of July, in the year 1553.
To the most excellent man, Thomas Blaurer, his most esteemed lord and friend in Kempten.
